awd_titl_txt: Epigenetic Inheritance of Physiological Phenotypes: Occurrence, Mechanism and Inter-and Intra-individual Variation
awd_abstract_narration:
The exact set of traits and features possessed by an animal (phenotypes) is shaped by genetic factors provided by maternal and paternal contributions to the genome.  The phenotypes are also shaped by so-called "epi-genetic" changes that impact gene expression but do not change the sequence of the DNA.  This award supports a two year EAGER project that focuses on the unexplored epigenetic inheritance of modified phenotypes of a higher-order physiological process, cardiovascular performance, and how physiological variation might result from mechanistic variation. Among key novel aspects of the proposed experiments is the focus on "true" transgenerational epigenetic inheritance in non-placental animals, rather than in utero or maternal effects. This project will focus on inter- and intra-individual variation in the underlying molecular mechanisms.  The significant Broader Impacts of this proposal include the cross-training of a cohort of both US students and Mexican graduate students (involving UNT's new agreement with Mexico's CONACyT funding agency). These students will receive training in the nexus of physiology and epigenetics as well as an enriched perspective on international research coordination.

Three hypotheses will be tested in the course of this project: H1: The Transgenerational Epigenetic Effect. Exposure to aquatic hypoxia in mature adult zebrafish (P0) before they begin reproduction will modify cardiovascular phenotype in their offspring (F1 and possibly F2 and beyond); H2: Epigenetic Dynamics. Epigenetically-inherited cardiovascular phenotypes are highly dynamic, showing both variation between individuals and slowly disappearing (fading out) across generations; and H3: Epigenetic Mechanisms. The germ-line of the P0 generation experiences variable degrees of DNA methylation and/or histone modification that lingers through subsequent fertilization and development, which may be correlated with variably altered gene expression and hence variation in the modified physiological phenotypes in the F1 generation. Data from this study are likely to underscore an emerging yet still vaguely defined rationale for why epigenetic inheritance has been selected for as a mechanism for surviving environmental changes that span several generations.  Results will be disseminated through publication in peer-reviewed journals and through presentation at scientific meetings.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The PI?s studies of transgenerational inheritance in the zebrafish as an animal model focused on both the non-genetically inherited phenotype and the mechanisms of  such inheritance ? e.g. (Bautista 2019, Bautista and Burggren 2019). Among the data reporting on morphology (e.g. pericardial fluid accumulation), egg production, sperm viability, cardio-respiratory physiology and behavior, two findings regarding non-genetically inherited phenotypes were especially remarkable:

  • The larvae of fishes whose parents had been exposed to select environmental stressors (hypoxia, Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons or PAHs) actually survived better in hypoxic or oiled water than in clean water!
  • F1 Larval fishes simultaneous inherited both adaptive traits (enhanced survival ? Fig. 1) and maladaptive traits (bradycardia ? Fig. 2), a finding increasing the sophistication of our view of epigenetic inheritance. Importantly, neither of these set of characteristics could have been genetically inherited, because mere exposure of the parents does not induce changes in gene sequence.

As part of this NSF grant, we have begun to explore the genetic underpinnings of these inherited characteristics, and how they are achieved.  Our findings suggest that epigenetic modification of gene expression (not changes in gene sequence) are involved.  Moreover, it looks like the environmental stressors of low oxygen and oil exposure have a similar, if not identical, pathway by which they act.

 

Broader Impacts: This NSF grant supported fully or in part the research of 4 research scientists/postdocs (2 women and/or minorities), 7 PhD students (7 women and/or minorities), 3 MSc students (3 women and/or minorities), ~15 high school students and 5 undergraduate students carrying out research experiences.  Three doctoral degrees were awarded to students supported in full or part by this NSF grant.

Additionally, UNT?s Biological Sciences Department has, under the PI?s leadership, continued to develop and expand a now-extensive and long-standing collaboration with the Biology Department of La Universidad Aut?noma del Estado de M?xico (UAEM) in Toluca, Mexico. The PI has hosted 4 Mexican PhD and MSc. Students, with two having already returned to faculty positions at UAEM.  We have also had a series of workshops ? alternatively in the USA and in Mexico that have been the catalyst in of ?heritage rediscovery? for US college students in a large but often ignored demographic in Texas and many other states. These are Hispanic/Latino individuals who as children were strongly directed into Anglo assimilation and consequently know little of their Latino culture, language and ancestry apart from middle and high school history classes. We know from experience that these workshops and activities springing from them create a truly transformative impact in the lives of this demographic because of the workshop?s dual focus on biology and culture. Newly aware and now proud of their heritage, these US college students become strong advocates of academic internationalization and multi-cultural aspects of science and those participating in it.
